node.title: Transferring material property to variable
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts,
I am trying to transfer a material property value to a variable using the following
Variable
[./pressure]
[../]

Kernel
[./value]
    type = MaterialPropertyValue
    prop_name = hydrostatic_stress
    variable = pressure
  [../]

Materials
 [./stress_pressure]
    type = RankTwoInvariant
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    property_name = hydrostatic_stress
    invariant = Hydrostatic
  [../]

I am getting the following error.
Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 1, dt = 1

Performing automatic scaling calculation

Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 1
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 1, time = 0.5, dt = 0.5
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 1
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 1


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 2


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 3


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 4


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 5


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 6


*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 7

Without it my simulation is coverging fine. I have tried decreasing the time step but still the same error is there.
Can you please suggest any solution?
Thanks,
Avtar

Make pressure an AuxVariable, and use an AuxKernel to perform the projection:
[AuxVariables]
  [pressure]
    order = FIRST # or CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = MaterialRealAux
      property = hydrostatic_stress
    []
  []
[]

Can I use this variable to couple with other variable?
I was following the following discussion
#22910
Thanks,
Avtar

Yes you can. But you lose the derivative information by projecting an AD material property onto an aux variable. However, if you are already using non-AD kernels and materials, you don't lose any derivative information -- it's still up to you how to compute the relevant derivatives for a good Jacobian (and preconditioner).

node.title: Output the radial stresses in spherical cordinates
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts,
I am using the following module to calculate the stresses in the spherical coordinates.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/StressDivergenceRSphericalTensors.html
Can you please suggest, how to get the output of stresses in spherical coordinate system? Is there any relevant examples?
Thanks,
Avtar

IIRC, if you use the axisymmetric RZ coordinate system in tensor mechanics, the strain and stress definitions are already in that coordinate system. The convention is
[ rr rz rt
  zr zz zt
  tr tz tt]

I suspect if you grab the corresponding component the same way as if you are in Cartesian, it will just work. But I agree this is a bit counter-intuitive, so hopefully there is a better way or it's been documented somewhere.

In addition to the page you linked, there is the spherical strain documentation page with a bit more information https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ADComputeRSphericalFiniteStrain.html. Note this formulation does assume a 1D problem

The new TM kernel system has a dedicated page for all that: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/interfaces/GradientOperator.html#2D_axisymmetric_cylindrical
Now that I look at it again, it is also somewhat incomplete...
Thanks. Its done.

node.title: PETSC test failure

Here is my settings
module purge
source /projects/netpub/gnu/gccvars.sh 11.3.0
module load cmake/3.22.3 openmpi-gnu/4.1 anaconda3/2022.05 
export PATH=/qscratch/bzeng/moose-compilers/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH
export CC=mpicc
export CXX=mpicxx
export F90=mpif90
export F77=mpif77
export FC=mpif90
source $HOME/.moose_profile

./configure CC=$CC CXX=$CXX F77=$F77 F90=$F90 FC=$FC --force \
--prefix=$PACKAGES_DIR/petsc-3.16.5 \
--with-debugging=0 \
--with-ssl=0 \
--with-pic=1 \
--with-openmp=1 \

--download-slepc=1 \
--download-hdf5=1 \
PETSC_DIR=`pwd` PETSC_ARCH=linux-opt

when compiling PETSC as moose submodule, I simply ran update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
The error message I got from both ways are the same.
Seems like it ran out of memory. Are you building petsc in parallel? If so, try building it with fewer processors. If possible, grab a compute node with more memory to compile petsc.

I guess this means it is correctly installed

node.title: missing some kernels when run
node.bodyText:
Hello, everyone. I meet a  quite strange "bug"
when i run this simple test.
#test the SideDiffusiveFluxAverage or SideFluxAverage
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  ymax = 2
[]

[Variables/temp]
  initial_condition = 300
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff_temp]
    type = Diffusion
    variable = temp
  []
  [Body_temp]
    type = Reaction
    variable = temp
    rate = 2
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    value = 0
    boundary = left
  []

  [right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = temp
    value = 2
    boundary = right
  []
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [sdfa]
   type = SideDiffusiveFluxAverage
   variable = temp
   boundary = bottom
   diffusivity = 1
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady

  solve_type = PJFNK
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

there seem the BodyForce kernel is no effect. and no error.
what should I do to check out the kernel?

my system is
  Model Name:	MacBook Air
  Model Identifier:	MacBookAir10,1
  Model Number:	MGN63CH/A
  Chip:	Apple M1
  Total Number of Cores:	8 (4 performance and 4 efficiency)
  Memory:	8 GB
  System Firmware Version:	8419.60.44
  OS Loader Version:	8419.60.44
  Serial Number (system):	FVFJ382FQ6L4
  Hardware UUID:	280938EB-9B01-50FC-A54E-9D077E872938
  Provisioning UDID:	00008103-000E54501420801E
  Activation Lock Status:	Disabled
Add more elements and try again.
Thanks, I did not think it was for this reason.

node.title: Where to find loading direction in source codes
node.bodyText:
Hello All
I need to add some lines in source codes to calculate schmid factor and need loading direction. Do you know which variable in the source codes is loading direction? The files I need to modify are 'CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate.C' and 'CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase.C'.
Thanks
Pengfei
@sapitts

I agree with @sapitts
The loading direction is not defined in the materials classes. On the contrary, the materials models response to the different load directions (and conditions) and initial orientations you may specify in your input file
Adding the loading direction as an input parameter sounds reasonable if you will need it in calculating the Schmid factor
If you are looking at an RVE, just homogenize the cauchy stress -- that's the "load" you use to compute the CRSS with Schmid.
Thank you for so detailed reply. How to provide the loading direction via an input parameter?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html

node.title: How to set periodic BC?
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I want to set the top and bottom boundary as periodic BC and left and right boundary as Neumann BC. The following shows how I set the BC, however, I found the phenomenon I got indicate that the BC setting is not correct. Can anyone give me some advice?

Thank you very much,
Best

Hello
Can you please post more about what indicates the setting bc is not correct. Is there a jump in the Y direction?
Guillaume

I ran several simulation of the layer propagation, with 2 different boundary conditions and compared them.
(1)Case 1
First BC I used is Neumann in all directions, I got the following first results

Then, by using another boundary condition, which is periodic for the top and bottom boundary and Neumann for the left and right, I got this result:

For the second simulation, the interface in the middle behaves differently as interfaces at the boundary.
(2) Case 2
Also, I ran another layer propagation simulation, First I use all Neumann BC for all the boundaries, and I got this,

Then, I use periodic for top and bottom boundary, Neumann for the left and right boundary, I got this,

From the periodic case, the triple junction behaviour in the middle is different from that at the boundaries.
Could you tell me how is the periodic BC implemented in MOOSE? Where can I get the periodic BC implementation code?
Also, is the 2D model in MOOSE really a 2D model, or, it is actually 3D, but with the third dimension unchanged?

The periodic BC is actually implemented in libmesh more than in MOOSE. You can have a look at the doxygen to look at the code but it will use some libmesh objects in there
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classAddPeriodicBCAction.html
The results you are getting look periodic to me
Should they match the neumann BC ? Why ? because of symmetry?

I still have a question about the dimension of model in MOOSE.
Also, are the 2D models in MOOSE really only have 2D or, it actually has 3D, but with the third dimension unchanged?
We have true 2D, with 2D elements, and true 3D with 3D elements

How does true 2D look like?

Is this true 2D? without the third axis, z.
the z here is 0, so this means the z axis does not exist?

QUAD4 are 2D eleemnts.
You dont need to specify the z parameters
How do you know? I did not find the introduction of QUAD4
have a look at libmesh doxygen for more info on QUAD4

node.title: MultiAppGeneralFieldShapeEvaluationTransfer Differences vs MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
node.bodyText:
Am I misusing the new transfer? I am getting different results on a simple example between the two transfers. I am using an example where the child app has a mesh that moves a lot and that movement needs to be captured.
Timestep 0: Both Transfers match

Timestep 10: MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer

Timestep 10: MultiAppGeneralFieldShapeEvaluationTransfer

parent.i
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = -1.0
    xmax = 3.0
    ymin = 0.0
    ymax = 1.0
    nx = 100
    ny = 25
    elem_type = QUAD4
  []
[]

[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
  skip_nl_system_check = true
  solve = false
  verbose_multiapps = true
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [indicator]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.0
  []
  [indicator_new]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.0
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt = 0.05
  num_steps = 10
[]

[Outputs]
  [out]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

[MultiApps]
  [solid_domain]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = child.i
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [pull_indicator]
    type = MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
    from_multi_app = solid_domain
    source_variable = solid_indicator
    variable = indicator
    displaced_source_mesh = true
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
  []
  [pull_indicator_new]
    type = MultiAppGeneralFieldShapeEvaluationTransfer
    from_multi_app = solid_domain
    source_variable = solid_indicator
    variable = indicator_new
    displaced_source_mesh = true
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
  []
[]


child.i
[GlobalParams]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

  [Mesh]
    [gen]
      type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
      dim = 2
      xmin = 0
      ymin = 0
      xmax = 0.2
      ymax = 0.5
      nx = 5
      ny = 15
      elem_type = QUAD4
    []
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  []

  [Variables]
    [disp_x][]
    [disp_y][]
  []

  [AuxVariables]
    [solid_indicator]
      initial_condition = 1.0
    []
  []

  [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
    [all]
      strain = SMALL
      incremental = true
    []
  []

  [Materials]
    [elastic_tensor]
      type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
      youngs_modulus = 10000.0
      poissons_ratio = 0.3
      use_displaced_mesh = true
    []
    [stress]
      type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    []
  []

  [BCs]
    [move_bottom_x]
      type = FunctionDirichletBC
      boundary = bottom
      variable = disp_x
      function = 't'
    []
    [move_bottom_y]
      type = DirichletBC
      boundary = bottom
      variable = disp_y
      value = '0'
    []
  []

  [Executioner]
    type = Transient
    num_steps = 1
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
    petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist               NONZERO'
    nl_max_its = 40
    l_max_its = 15
    line_search = 'none'
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-4
    automatic_scaling = true
  []

Thanks for reporting. I ll take a look
The new transfer passes all the tests for displaced meshes, but you're the first to actually use it on displaced meshes.
first finding is that the problem is limited to LAGRANGE target variables. Constant monomials and higher order elemental for the target variable work fine.

ok found the issue, the point locators are created only on initialSetup and if there s displacement we need to refresh them every timestep
I m going to put a PR up for MOOSE today. If you need a today fix you can also change in MultiAppGeneralFieldTransfer.C
  params.addParam<bool>(
      "from_app_must_contain_point",
      false,    // instead of true

This will bypass the point locators in that transfer

#23360 has been merged.
Please let me know if the problem is not solved. I changed your input a bit before adding it as a test to MOOSE

Sorry for the delay. The Teams recording is proving to be a little more difficult to cut up than expected. It will be posted to the same channel either tomorrow or at the beginning of next week (this Friday is our day off).
Logan, that would be great, thanks!

node.title: Homogenization for non regular and non orthogonal mesh
node.bodyText: I am trying to perform asymptotic homogenization of a periodic structure wherein the unit cell is a rhombus. Is there a way to run the homogenization process using the AsymptoticExpansionHomogenizationKernel?
@jasondhales you're the author of that object
I haven't tried it, but my guess is that as long as you set up the periodic boundary conditions properly, it will work.

Is it possible to change the repeating axes orientation? For example, when defining the periodic BC for a square unit cell, the repeating axes (X and Y) are perpendicular to each other and coincident with the Cartesian plane. However, for a rhombus type unit cell, this wouldn't be case.
